title: How to Verify Funds Before Cashing a Check

steps.title: Identify the name of the payer’s bank on the check.
steps.content: Identify the name of the payer’s bank on the check. The bank’s name is printed on the front of the check, and is often found below the check amount or at the top of the check.

steps.title: Find the bank’s contact information.
steps.content: Find the bank’s contact information. Verifying funds for a check requires you to call the bank directly, or visit a branch in person. [1] X Research source Use the Internet or a telephone directory to find the bank’s contact information, instead of relying on contact information printed on the check. This helps you avoid contacting an illegitimate party claiming to be a bank in the event the check is counterfeit.

steps.title: Call the payer’s bank, or visit a branch in person.
steps.content: Call the payer’s bank, or visit a branch in person. Some banks can verify funds over the telephone, whereas others require you to visit a branch in person. For example, Wells Fargo and Chase allow you to verify funds over the phone, while Citibank and Bank of America require you to verify funds in person.

steps.title: Inform a bank representative that you want to verify funds for a check.
steps.content: Inform a bank representative that you want to verify funds for a check. Policies vary for each bank and financial institution, and some require you to pay a fee to verify funds. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Provide the bank with the payer’s account information as required.
steps.content: Provide the bank with the payer’s account information as required. In most cases, you’ll be asked to provide the payer’s name, account number, and the amount of the check.

steps.title: Wait for the bank to inform you whether funds are available.
steps.content: Wait for the bank to inform you whether funds are available. Due to rules and regulations concerning privacy, most banks can only tell you whether funds are available, but cannot reveal any other account information, such as the amount of funds available, or whether other transactions are pending.

steps.title: Sign up for a third-party check verification service.
steps.content: Sign up for a third-party check verification service. Check verification services can’t necessarily confirm whether funds are available, but can determine whether you’re at risk for cashing a bad check based on the payer’s financial history. Examples of reputable check verification services are ChexSystems, CrossCheck, and Certegy. [3] X Research source Ask your bank for recommendations on reputable check verification services if you need help choosing a service.

steps.title: Provide the check verification service with required information about the payer.
steps.content: Provide the check verification service with required information about the payer. This often includes the payer’s name, address, and financial institution.

steps.title: Wait for the check verification service to provide feedback on the payer’s financial history.
steps.content: Wait for the check verification service to provide feedback on the payer’s financial history. Most check verification services can confirm whether the payer’s bank account is valid, whether the payer has a history of writing bad checks, and whether an account is open and has funds available.

steps.title: Ask the check verification service whether you should cash the check based on its findings.
steps.content: Ask the check verification service whether you should cash the check based on its findings. A great verification service will recommend whether or not you should move forward with cashing a check based on the payer’s financial history.
